poem:
### Gauke's Examined Remedy

Beneath towering cells—  
a ripple of change:  
discard chains of  
brief confinement.  
  
Time yields  
space, whispers  
of reformed streets,  
uncluttered by  
short stays.  
  
Echoes of vanished  
doors creak open,  
a call to uncrowd  
our walls—  
justice measured  
by a heartbeat.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What are the ‘radical’ proposed reforms to UK criminal sentencing? A series of “radical” proposed reforms to criminal sentencing have been submitted to ministers by the former justice secretary David Gauke, who has said that, if implemented, they should solve the UK’s prison overcrowding problem. The government has confirmed that most of his recommendations will be accepted. But what are they? Largely scrap short sentences Gauke’s review suggests sentences of less than a year be". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
